text.content:
Reorder Items

All items in a list can be reordered by dragging and dropping an item by the horizontal grip lines to the left of the item. Languages can also be nested by dropping the item onto another item.

Show/Hide Items

All items in a list can be shown or hidden by clicking the checkbox to the left of the item.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Abilities

Create an Ability

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

    Note

    An auto-generated Key is provided, but it's best to replace it with a simple three-letter key.

  3. Enter a Full Key.

  4. Enter a Label.

  5. Enter an Abbreviation.

  6. (Optional) Check Include for ASI.

    Note

    Checking Include for ASI allows the ability to improved by an Ability Score Improvement (ASI).

  7. Select a Type: 'Mental' or 'Physical'.

  8. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

    Note

    For a tooltip to appear, the Reference must be linked to a journal entry with the "Rule" page type, and the tooltip content should be entered in the Tooltip section using the "Ability" rule type.

  9. Click Save and Close.

Example Ability

Property

Value

Key

luc

Full Key

luck

Label

Luck

Abbreviation

luc

Include for ASI

Type

Mental

Reference

Compendium.world.my-rules.JournalEntry.r04xTaCjv1UK6GJn.JournalEntryPage.pVHCdBd6kRX3zyyE

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Actor Sizes

Create an Actor Size

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Label.

  3. Enter an Abbreviation.

  4. Enter Hit Die.

  5. Enter a Token Size.

    Note

    Token Size determines the token's size relative to a scene's Grid Size. For example: 1 would be one times the grid size, 4 would be four times the grid size.

  6. (Optional) Enter a Dynamic Token Scale.

    Note

    Dynamic Token Scale corrects the size of the token's image when using a dynamic ring. For example: 1 would be 100% or no change and 0.5 would be 50%.

  7. Enter a Capacity Multiplier.

  8. Click Save and Close.

Example Actor Size

Property

Value

Label

Colossal

Abbreviation

Cl

Hit Die

20

Token Size

5

Capacity Multiplier

5

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Armor

Create an Armor

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Create a base item for the armor.

    Note

    Base armor details, including its Equipment Type (e.g., Light Armor, Medium Armor, Heavy Armor), are contained within an item stored within a compendium. To create a new armor, you will need to create an Item compendium and create a base item within it.

  4. Paste the item's UUID.

    Tip

    You can copy an item's UUID by opening up the item and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Armor

Property

Value

Key

greathelm

ID

Compendium.world.my-items.Item.hU51WZiTbOeYUbAf

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Armor Calculations

Create an Armor Calculation

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Label.

  3. Enter a Formula.

    Tip

    For available formula properties, visit Roll Formulas.

  4. Click Save and Close.

Example Armor Calculation

Property

Value

Label

Intelligent Defense

Formula

10 + @abilities.dex.mod + @abilities.int.mod

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Armor Proficiencies

The Armor Proficiencies configuration includes both Armor Proficiencies (Light, Medium, Heavy, and Shields) and Armor Types (Light Armor, Medium Armor, Heavy Armor, Shield, and Natural Armor). An Armor Proficiency groups one or more Armor Types together.

For an Armor Type to show on a character sheet, it must be linked to an Armor Proficiency and a base item must exist with the matching Armor Type (see Create a New Armor). Similarly, an Armor Proficiency will only appear if it includes at least one Armor Type.

Create an Armor Type

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

  4. (Optional) Drag and drop the new armor type onto an Armor Proficiency.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Armor Type

Property

Value

Key

buckler

Label

Buckler

Armor Proficiency

Drag and drop onto Shields

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Conditions

While core conditions are included to let users hide or edit their properties, proceed with caution—modifying these conditions may disrupt core functionality. For instance, the Exhaustion condition cannot be hidden because it's essential for the character sheet to function properly.

If issues arise from editing core conditions, you can restore the default settings. To reset all conditions to the core list, click the Reset to Default button in the Configure Conditions window. To reset a single condition, click the Edit button for that condition, then select Reset to Default in the Edit Condition window.

Create a Condition

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

    Warning

    The key must only contain alphanumeric characters.

  3. Enter a Label.

  4. Pick an Icon.

  5. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

    Note

    For a tooltip to appear, the Reference must be linked to a journal entry with the "Rule" page type, and the tooltip content should be entered in the Tooltip section using the "Condition" rule type.

    If you leave the Reference field empty, the condition button on the character sheet will lose some styling. If you don’t have a specific reference, you can add placeholder text to avoid this styling issue.

  6. (Optional) Check Include on HUD.

    Note

    This determines whether the condition will show in the Token HUD's status effects menu.

  7. (Optional) Check Include on Sheet.

    Note

    This determines whether the condition will show under Conditions on the character sheet.

  8. Click Save and Close.

Example Condition

Property

Value

Key

starved

Label

Starved

Icon

my-icons/starved.svg

Reference

Compendium.world.my-rules.JournalEntry.1TpkbEoS1K4WqKWX.JournalEntryPage.ObX4m75A6XRG1sG0

Include on HUD

Include on Sheet

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Currency

Note

New currencies cannot be created currently.

Modify a Currency

  • Hide a currency by unticking the checkbox.

  • Rename a currency by editing the Label.

  • Change the Conversion Rate.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Damage Types

  4. (Optional) Pick an Icon.

  5. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into the Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

    Note

    For a tooltip to appear, the Reference must be linked to a journal entry with the "Rule" page type, and the tooltip content should be entered in the Tooltip section using the "Damage Type" rule type.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Encumbrance

Note

The Configure Encumbrance form displays values in either imperial or metric units, depending on the "Use Metric Weight Units" setting found under Game Settings > Configure Settings > Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition.

Effects

Effects are applied when a creature reaches the encumbrance thresholds. Modify the Label and Icon for each status effect as needed.

Thresholds

Thresholds determine when a status effect is applied and set position of threshold markers in relation to the Maximum threshold. For example, by default, the Encumbered status activates at 33% of the maximum while Heavily Encumbered activates at 66%.

Speed Reduction

Speed is reduced by the Speed Reduction value when a creature reaches a threshold. For instance, with default settings, a creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet when they hit the Encumbered threshold.

Currency per Weight

The Currency Per Weight determines how many coins equal one base weight unit (either pounds or kilograms).

Vehicle Weight Multiplier

The Vehicle Weight Multiplier adjusts a vehicle's carrying capacity.

Weight Modifiers

Weight Modifiers adjust the weight of items based on their properties. These modifiers are percentages: a value of 0 reduces the item's weight by 100%, 0.5 reduces the item's weight by 50% and 1.25 increases the weight by 25%.

Modifiers don't stack; instead, the lower modifier applies when two or more affect the same item. For example, if the Equipped Item Weight Modifier is 0.75 and the Proficient & Equipped Item Modifier is 0.5, the item's weight will be reduced by 50% (0.5) when both properties apply.

  • Equipped Item Weight Modifier: Adjusts the weight of all equipped items.

  • Proficient & Equipped Item Weight Modifier: Adjusts the weight of items the creature has equipped and is proficient in.

  • Unequipped Item Weight Modifier: Adjusts the weight of all unequipped items.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Item Action Types

Note

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Item Properties

Create an Item Property

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

    Note

    You can ignore the Abbreviation, Icon and Tag properties as they currently have no function for new Item Properties.

  4. (Optional) Check Physical.

  5. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

  6. Check required Item Types.

  7. Click Save and Close.

Example Item Property

Property

Value

Key

aem

Label

Aetherium

Physical

Reference

Compendium.world.my-rules.JournalEntry.r04xTaCjv1UK6GJn.JournalEntryPage.WIdCHQ6OBiFgt3OA

Item Types

Container, Equipment, Loot, Tool, Weapon

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Languages

Tip

Items can be rearranged by dragging and dropping them using the horizontal grip lines on the left. A red line will appear to indicate where the item will be placed. To nest items, simply drop one item onto another; a red box will highlight the hovered item, showing where it will be nested.

Create a Language

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

  4. (Optional) Drag and drop the new language into a language group.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Language

Property

Value

Key

snaketongue

Label

Snaketongue

Group

Drag and drop onto Exotic Languages

  1. Edit the Max Level.

  2. Click Save Changes.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Skills

Create a Skill

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Full Key.

  4. Enter a Label.

  5. Enter an Ability.

  6. (Optional) Pick an Icon.

  7. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

    Note

    For a tooltip to appear, the Reference must be linked to a journal entry with the "Rule" page type, and the tooltip content should be entered in the Tooltip section using the "Skill" rule type.

  8. (Optional) Select a Roll Mode.

    Note

    Setting the Roll Mode will override the setting in the Configure Rolls form. Leave as "Default" to use the mode from the Configure Rolls form.

  9. Click Save and Close.

Example Skill

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Weapon Proficiencies

The Weapon Proficiencies configuration includes both Weapon Proficiencies (Simple, Martial) and Weapon Types (Simple Melee, Simple Ranged, Martial Melee, Martial Ranged, Natural Weapons). A Weapon Proficiency groups one or more Weapon Types together.

For a Weapon Type to show on a character sheet, it must be linked to a Weapon Proficiency and a base item must exist with the matching Weapon Type (see Create a New Weapon). Similarly, a Weapon Proficiency will only appear if it includes at least one Weapon Type.

Create a Weapon Type

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

  4. (Optional) Drag and drop the new Weapon Type onto a Weapon Proficiency.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Weapon Type

Property

Value

Key

stiletto

Label

Stiletto

Weapon Proficiency

Drag and drop onto Simple Melee

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Activation Costs

Note

Only available in D&D 5e system version 4+.

Create an Activation Cost

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Label.

  3. (Optional) Enter a Group.

    Note

    The Group determines which heading the activation cost will be nested under in the Activation Cost menu. If left blank, the item will remain unnested.

  4. (Optional) Check Scalar.

    Note

    Checking Scalar means the activation cost requires a variable amount. For example, the "Minutes" activation cost requires a specific amount, like 10 minutes, while "Action" always represents a single action.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Ability

Property

Value

Label

Years

Group

Time

Scalar

  5. Click Save and Close.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Rolls

Always wanted to roll 1d4 for initiative, use 2d10 instead of 1d20, or make skill checks private by default? The Configure Rolls form lets you customize the base die and roll mode for Ability Checks, Attack Rolls, Concentration Saving Throws, Initiative Rolls, Saving Throws, Skill Checks and Tool Checks.

To change a base die, enter the desired number and type of die in the die notation format, for example: 1d6, 2d10, 1d10, etc.

Note

If you use multiple base dice (e.g., 2d10), Advantage and Disadvantage will double the dice rolled, keeping the highest or lowest two, respectively. For Elven Accuracy, the number of base dice is tripled.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e

  1. Edit the Max Ability Score.

  2. Click Save Changes.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Tool Proficiencies

Tool Proficiencies consist of Tool Proficiencies and Tool Types, where each Tool Type is nested within a Tool Proficiency. Unlike Armor and Weapon Proficiencies, a Tool Proficiency must contain exactly one Tool Type, and both must share the same key and label.

  • A Tool Proficiency without a Tool Type appears under the Other section in the Tool Proficiencies window.
  • Tools created under Configure Tools without an assigned Tool Type also appear under Other.
  • For a tool to be linked to a Tool Proficiency, the Tool Proficiency must contain a Tool Type, and a matching base item must exist (see Create a New Tool).

Create a Tool Proficiency

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

  4. Click Save and Close.

Example Tool Proficiency

Property

Value

Key

tech

Label

Technology

Create a Tool Type

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key matching an existing Tool Proficiency.

  3. Enter a Label matching an existing Tool Proficiency

  4. Drag and drop the new Tool Type onto the matching Tool Proficiency.

  5. Click Save and Close.

Example Tool Type

Property

Value

Key

tech

Label

Technology

Tool Proficiency

Drag and drop onto Technology

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Bloodied

Status

Choose if Bloodied automation is enabled and whether it applies to just allies (players) or both allies and enemies (npcs).

  • Core Setting: This setting mimics the core D&D 5e Bloodied Status setting and when Override Bloodied is disabled, changing the setting here will also update the core setting (found in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition > Configure Visibility).

Name

Change the name for Bloodied.

Icon

Choose a custom icon for the Bloodied condition and status effect.

Threshold

Set when Bloodied will be applied. 0.5 is at or below 50% of max HP.

Override Bloodied

When enabled, this setting overrides the core Bloodied automation. Custom D&D 5e includes its own Bloodied automation, but also adds Bloodied as a condition on the character sheet and as a status effect on the Token HUD.

  • Immunity to Bloodied: Add Bloodied as a condition immunity to a character or NPC to stop the Bloodied condition from applying to them.

Note: Enabling this setting will automatically disable the built-in D&D 5e Bloodied Status setting (found in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition > Configure Visibility).

Remove on Dead

Remove the Bloodied condition when a creature has the Dead status effect. Only applies when Override Bloodied is enabled.

Tint

Enter a color in hex format (e.g., #ff0000 for red) to visually tint the token when it has the Bloodied condition. This helps to quickly identify Bloodied creatures on the map. Leave empty for no tint.

Located in Game Settings > Configure Settings > Custom D&D 5e > Configure Creature Types

Create a Creature Type

  1. Click Create New.

  2. Enter a Key.

  3. Enter a Label.

  5. (Optional) Pick an Icon.

  6. (Optional) Paste a journal entry's UUID into the Reference.

    Tip

    You can copy a journal entry's UUID by opening up the entry and left-clicking the passport icon in the window's header.

    Note

    For a tooltip to appear, the Reference must be linked to a journal entry with the "Rule" page type, and the tooltip content should be entered in the Tooltip section using the "Damage Type" rule type.

  7. (Optional) Tick Detect Alignment.

  8. Click Save and Close.
